title: Cerulean flycatcher
text:
The cerulean flycatcher ("Eutrichomyias rowleyi") is a medium-sized (up to 18 cm long), blue <a href="passerine">passerine</a> with bright cerulean blue plumage, a bare white orbital ring, dark brown <a href="Iris%20%28anatomy%29">iris</a>, bluish black <a href="Beak">bill</a> and pale blue-grey below. The young has a shorter tail and grey underparts. It is the only member of the monotypic genus Eutrichomyias. Although it resembles a <a href="monarch%20flycatcher">monarch flycatcher</a>, it is actually related to the <a href="Fantail">fantails</a>.
Taxonomy and systematics.
The scientific name commemorates the British explorer and ornithologist <a href="George%20Dawson%20Rowley">George Dawson Rowley</a>. The cerulean flycatcher was originally described in the genus "<a href="Zeocephus">Zeocephus</a>", and until recently was known as the cerulean paradise-flycatcher. Alternate names include Rowley's flycatcher and Rowley's paradise-flycatcher. Although initially classified in <a href="Monarch%20flycatcher">Monarchidae</a>, a 2017 study involving sequencing of DNA from the type specimen found that it was a member of the <a href="fantail">fantail</a> family <a href="Rhipiduridae">Rhipiduridae</a>, being classified in the basal subfamily <a href="Rhipiduridae">Lamproliinae</a> (sometimes considered a distinct family) along with "<a href="Chaetorhynchus">Chaetorhynchus</a>" and "<a href="Lamprolia">Lamprolia</a>." This finding was accepted by the <a href="International%20Ornithologists%27%20Union">IOC</a>, who renamed the species from "cerulean paradise-flycatcher" to just "cerulean flycatcher".
Distribution and habitat.
The cerulean flycatcher is <a href="Endemism%20in%20birds">endemic</a> to the island of <a href="Sangihe%20Island">Sangihe</a>, off <a href="North%20Sulawesi">North Sulawesi</a> in Indonesia. Previously known only from a single specimen collected in 1873, this rare bird was rediscovered in October 1998 around forested valleys of <a href="Mount%20Sahendaruman">Mount Sahendaruman</a> in southern Sangihe.
Behaviour and ecology.
Food and feeding.
Its diet consists mainly of insects and other small invertebrates.
Threats.
Due to ongoing habitat loss, a small population size, and limited range, the cerulean flycatcher is evaluated as <a href="Critically%20Endangered">Critically Endangered</a> on the <a href="IUCN%20Red%20List">IUCN Red List</a> of Threatened Species.
